I.  THE PROPOSED PROJECT 
 
1.  The proposed transaction technical assistance (TRTA) is for the Asian Development Bank 
(ADB) to design, setup, and operationalize the ADB Ventures Investment Fund 2 (Fund 2) under 
the ADB Ventures Financing Partnerships Facility (ADB Ventures). Approved by the Board on the 
31 January 2020 for an indicative funding target exceeding $200 million, ADB Ventures supports 
and invests in early-stage technology companies that contribute to achieving the Sustainable 
Development Goals (SDGs) in emerging Asia-Pacific.1,2 ADB Ventures currently houses the ADB 
Ventures Investment Fund 1 (Fund 1) and the ADB Ventures technical assistance (the TA). 
Fund 1 reached final close on 24 September 2020 at $60 million capitalization and provides equity 
financing up to $4 million per investment.3 The TA is being implemented during 2020-2022 to 
leverage  ADB’s  extensive  operational  network  to  generate  investment  pipeline.  As  of 
15 November 2020, the TA was funded at about $7.6 million.4 
 
2.  ADB  Ventures  fills  an  operational  gap  allowing  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Operations 
Department to provide funding at all stages of the business life cycle of early-stage technology 
companies. Fund 2 will complement Fund 1 by providing debt financing indicatively up to 
$8 million  to  technology  companies  transitioning  from  equity-financed  to  leveraged  growth. 
Fund 2 will indicatively focus on cleantech and agriculture technology companies which are 
typically more capital-intensive. Debt financing is often needed to help these companies deploy 
their product solutions at scale to accelerate commercialization and SDG impact. 
     
II.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Justification 
 
3.  Challenge: The Asia-Pacific has made great strides in poverty reduction and economic 
growth, but is not on track to achieve any of the 17 SDGs by 2030.5 In particular the region needs 
to  significantly  accelerate  its  progress  on  environmental  sustainability.6  The  outbreak  of 
coronavirus disease (COVID-19) has further stalled progress. Falling fiscal revenues and higher 
public spending to strengthen public healthcare systems and mitigate the economic impact of 
COVID-19 will constrain public sector resources available for much-needed green and social 
investments.  ADB  developing  member  countries  (DMC)  will  need  to  unlock  private  sector 
resources to finance a green and inclusive recovery in emerging Asia-Pacific.7 
 
4.  Opportunity:  The  plummeting  cost  of  technology  is  creating  opportunities  to 
commercialize technology solutions that solve big development problems in the region.8,9 These 
 
1  ADB. 2020. Establishment of the ADB Ventures Financing Partnership Facility. 
2  Target investees are companies with technology-enabled business models operating in ADB DMCs. 
3  Fund 1 investors include the Ministry for Foreign Affairs Finland, the Clean Technology Fund, the Korea Venture 
Investment Corporation, the Nordic Development Fund, and the Ministry of Economy and Finance Republic of Korea.  
4  Including funding from TASF ($2 million), the Clean Technology Fund ($3 million), the Asia Climate Finance Fund 
($1.4 million) and Nordic Development Fund (Euro 1 million). ADB’s Private Sector Operations Department has 
earmarked $2 million TASF from the 2021 budget, and $1 million in 2022. Fundraising for a balance of $1.4 million 
is ongoing to reach the total TA target of $ 12 million. 
5  United Nations Economic and Social Commission for the Asia and the Pacific. 2020. Asia and the Pacific SDG 
Progress Report 2020.  
6  Top SDG priorities in the Asia-Pacific include responsible consumption and production, and climate action.  
7  ADB. Forthcoming. Asian Development Outlook 2021: Financing a Green and Inclusive Recovery. 
8  PricewaterhouseCoopers. 2020. The State of Climate Tech 2020: The next frontier for venture capital. 
9  For example, the average price for battery packs has fallen by 87% in real terms to $156 per kilowatt hour during 
2010-2019 (see Bloomberg New Energy Finance 2019 Battery Price Survey).

2   
 
include inefficient energy consumption that is generating unsustainable levels of greenhouse gas 
emissions, climate-related hazards and disasters triggered by natural hazards, poor air quality 
and waste management in cities, and the adverse impact of human activities on marine and 
coastal ecosystems. 
 
5.  Problem: Many of the technology solutions needed to tackle these problems already exist 
but have not yet been deployed and/or commercialized at scale in emerging Asia-Pacific. Since 
2015, venture capital (VC) portfolios have tended to be concentrated in developed economies, 
later-stage deals, and software technologies such as e-commerce. VC funding has been more 
limited to some sectors highly relevant to the SDGs. From 2016-2019, only 2% and 1% of VC 
deals in the Asia-Pacific were for cleantech and agricultural technology, respectively.10 The path 
toward technology commercialization is typically longer for this category of technology solutions. 
The payback period is likely to be even more uncertain for hardware and/or hard science 
technology solutions that tend to be more capital intensive. These factors alter the risk-return 
profile of these technologies making them less attractive to venture capital investors.11 Beyond 
product development, entrepreneurs venturing into emerging Asia-Pacific markets will likely need 
to navigate at least one of the following significant hurdles:12  
 
i.  Market validation. Markets in emerging Asia-Pacific are diverse and fragmented 
by  language,  geography,  culture,  and  business  enabling  environment. 
Technologies and business models must be adapted market-by-market to a variety 
of  norms,  often  amid  limited  market  information  and  low  transparency.  User 
demand for technology solutions is rarely articulated in a way that attracts interest 
from technology providers. It can be expensive and time-consuming to get buy-in 
from incumbents with long and risk-adverse development cycles. Market entry 
transaction costs are even more acute in the Asia-Pacific’s smaller and more 
remote  markets.  The  private  sector  has  proven  reluctant  to  invest  there,  as 
technology innovators often consider it easier to focus on larger and more mature 
markets. Those that decide to venture into developing Asia-Pacific often face 
heightened market risks including opaque legal and regulatory frameworks. 
 
ii.  Scaling deployment. Climate impact technology businesses in the scale-up stage 
(i.e. post product development and validation) often require a significant amount of 
up-front capital expenditure. While potentially offering solid long-term paybacks, the 
growth  trajectory  of  these  companies  tends  to  be  relatively  slow  so  raising 
additional—and often large amounts of—capital through additional VC funding is 
often not an option. Debt financing options are also limited as traditional debt 
providers generally prefer to lend to companies with established and stable cash 
flows.  Technology  companies  transitioning  from  equity-financed  to  leveraged 
growth may be at or near positive unit economics, but still perceived by traditional 
lenders to be too risky due to their limited operational track record and inability to 
offer sufficient physical assets as collateral. The lack of affordable debt is therefore 
preventing these technologies reaching emerging markets at scale. 
 
6.  Nascent VC markets in emerging Asia-Pacific. Although there is a growing pool of 
patient capital from diversified sources – including corporate VC funds, foundations, and family 
 
10 Pitchbook Database (accessed 31 October 2020). 
11 Massachusetts Institute of Technology. 2016. Venture Capital and Cleantech: The Wrong Model for Clean Energy 
Innovation. 
12 Rocky Mountain Institute. 2020. Climate Tech’s Four Valleys of Death and Why We Must Build a Bridge.

3 
 
offices  –  venture-stage  financing,  particularly  venture-stage  debt  financing,  to  support 
entrepreneurs overcome these hurdles remains limited in emerging Asia-Pacific. These funding 
sources remain fragmented and struggle to understand complexities across emerging Asia-
Pacific markets. In developed economies the venture-stage debt market has evolved as a 
financing category to help technology companies transitioning from equity-driven to leveraged 
growth. This market is however still nascent in the Asia-Pacific. There are also rich opportunities 
for advancing gender equality given that women-led enterprises attracted less than 3% of global 
venture capital funding.13 
 
7.  Strategy 2030 priorities. ADB’s Strategy 2030 emphasizes the importance of innovative 
technologies in addressing development challenges in emerging Asia-Pacific. Strategy 2030 
Operational Plans prioritize scaling up ADB’s support to addressing climate change, building 
climate resilience, ensuring environmental sustainability, tackling the water-food-energy nexus, 
and  accelerating  gender  equality. 14  Strategy  2030  also  commits  to  expanding  ADB’s 
nonsovereign operations in frontier markets by considering smaller deal sizes with potentially 
higher risk and development impact.   
 
8.  Important  pilot  initiative.  ADB  Ventures  is  an  important  pilot  initiative  that  has 
implications for future funds as well as ADB’s core operations and future business process 
reforms. Key lessons so far include: (i) the understanding that there will be significant learnings 
from both the successes and failures of investing in early-stage technology companies; ADB can 
capture these learnings to better advise and serve traditional clients; (ii) ADB is taking a portfolio 
approach for a small, ringfenced set of investments which allows for higher risk and greater 
developmental impact at the project level; if successful, this approach could eventually be 
integrated into ADB’s mainstream nonsovereign operations; (iii) ADB Ventures is testing the 
approach of involving external investment experts in ADB’s investment decision making process 
without compromising ADB safeguard polices and integrity procedures; and, (iv) TA resources 
can be used to leverage ADB’s operational networks, relationships, and strategic partnerships to 
generate bankable early-stage projects and crowd in risk capital towards achieving the SDGs.15,16  
 
B.  Outcome and Outputs 
 
9.  Impact and outcome. Fund 2 will enable ADB Ventures to generate greater impact by 
further catalyzing venture-risk-capital funding towards achievement of the SDGs in the Asia-
Pacific. The outcome will be operationalization of Fund 2 (Linked Document 1). Along with Fund 
1 and the TA, the suite of ADB Ventures financing modalities will allow ADB to provide funding 
across multiple stages of the business life cycle of technology companies. Fund 1 and the TA will 
help early-stage companies validate their technology solutions in emerging Asia-Pacific markets. 
Fund 2 will support technology companies transitioning from equity-driven to leveraged growth. 
ADB Ventures will encourage cross-border market expansion of technology providers to ADB’s 
DMCs through network partnerships in both developed and developing economies (para. 17). 
 
10.  ADB Ventures Investment Fund 2. The design of ADB Ventures Investment Fund 2 will 
be informed by TRTA outputs detailed in para 14 and build on the lessons from past and on-going 
ADB Ventures operations (para. 8). Fund 2 will aim to crowd in commercial risk capital for a 
 
13 International Finance Corporation. 2019. Moving Towards Gender Balance in Private Equity and Venture Capital. 
14 ADB. 2019. Strategy 2030 Operation Plans. Manila (https://www.adb.org/about/strategy-2030-operational-priorities) 
15 ADB. Forthcoming in 2021. Technical Assistance Completion Report: Mekong Business Initiative. 
16 Under the TRTA for the Preparation of the ADB Ventures Facility, ADB piloted approaches to match technology 
solution providers with corporate end users in the following areas: energy efficient buildings, sustainable agriculture, 
sustainable travel and tourism, and resilience against water scarcity  (www.ventures.adb.org/labs/).

4   
 
diversified portfolio of technology companies that support a green and inclusive recovery for 
accelerated SDG impact in emerging Asia-Pacific. ADB is currently seeking funding commitments 
of at least $100 million to establish and operationalize Fund 2.17 Fund 2 will provide debt financing 
indicatively up to $8 million per transaction to technology companies (indicatively Series B stage 
and beyond).18,19  Fund 2 will seek to coinvest with and therefore catalyze commercial venture risk 
capital. Fund 2’s target projects are envisaged as companies that: (i) emerge from ADB Ventures 
investment and TA activities, as well as other relevant ADB operations; (ii) are cofinanced with 
commercial investors (including VCs, corporates, and financial institutions); and (iii) benefit from 
ADB’s technical additionality (para 13). Aligned to Fund 1 operations, Fund 2 will primarily target 
Southeast Asia and South Asia. The structure and commercial terms of Fund 2 will be determined 
by diagnostics under this TRTA (output 1). Approval for the establishment and administration of 
Fund 2 will be sought separately once fund-raising discussions have resulted in the necessary 
commitments by third-party funders. ADB will aim for Fund 2 to become operational by 31 
December 2021. 
 
11.  Climate  Impact.  Fund 2  will  apply  a  climate  impact  investing  lens to  evaluate the 
company’s contribution to climate impact, including: (i) climate mitigation – reduction or prevention 
of greenhouse gas emissions, (ii) climate adaptation – prevention or reduction in the adverse 
impact of climate change, and (iii) climate resilience – increasing the ability and capacity to 
recover from the adverse impacts of climate change.   
 
12.  Gender Impact. Fund 2 will apply a gender equality scorecard to evaluate the company’s 
gender inclusiveness on six dimensions: suppliers, customers, ownership, leadership, workers, 
and institutional practices.    
 
13.  ADB additionality. Fund 2 operations will benefit from ADB’s unique convening power, 
expertise,  and  resources  to  crowd  technology  and  investment  into  emerging  markets. 
Nonfinancial additionality includes (i) risk mitigation, by being an honest broker to convene and 
leverage ADB’s expansive regional networks and both sovereign and non-sovereign relationships; 
(ii) standard setting, by encouraging improved standards of environmental and social safeguards, 
corporate  governance,  and  impact  monitoring  early-stage  companies  grow  and  scale;  and 
(iii) knowledge, innovation, and capacity-building, by encouraging global and regional technology 
transfers through operating at scale and sustaining long-term strategic partnership engagements 
across  ADB’s  DMCs.  Financial  additionality  includes  (i)  an  innovative  financing  structure, 
including the provision of patient capital and debt financing that is not readily available in the 
venture capital market in emerging Asia-Pacific; and (ii) resource mobilization, as a result of 
ADB’s involvement that crowds in commercial sources of venture capital.20 
 
14.  Outputs. The major outputs and activities are summarized in Table 1. 
 
Table 1: Summary of Major Output and Activities 
Major Outputs  Key Activities 
   
1. ADB Ventures  1.1 Early-stage financing analysis: Prepare demand and supply analysis about

  1.2 Structure and design of the fund: Prepare Fund 2 design report based on

20  World Bank. 2018. Multilateral Development Banks’ Harmonized Framework for Additionality in Private Sector 
Operations (English). Washington, D.C.

5 
 
  review of regulatory regime for venture-stage debt financing in emerging Asia 
  markets. The report will detail the structure and design of the proposed fund, 
  including legal structure, commercial terms, governance arrangements and 
  portfolio management, leveraging both external and internal experience with 
  similar venture-stage debt funds (Q1 2021 – Q2 2021). 
 
2. ADB Ventures

ADB=Asian Development Bank; Q = quarter

C.  Cost and Indicative Financing 
 
15.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $1,000,000. It will initially be funded for $500,000 financed 
on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s  Technical  Assistance  Special  Fund  ($200,000,  TASF-donor 
contribution and $300,000, TASF-income transfer). Cost estimates and financing arrangements 
are in Appendix 1. ADB will seek out cofinancing for the remaining $500,000 balance.21  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency of the TRTA, which will be implemented between 
December 2020 and December 2021. The Business Development Unit in ADB’s Private Sector 
Operations Department will manage and administer the TRTA. ADB Ventures will adopt a One 
ADB approach, working closely with the ADB’s regional and knowledge departments to leverage 
ADB’s operational networks, relationships, and knowledge.  
 
17.  Partnerships. ADB Ventures will continue to seek out new partners, including (i) network 
partners in both ADB’s developed and developing member countries that will partner with ADB to 
source global and regional impact technology solutions; and (ii) funding partners for Fund 2. 
 
18.  Consulting Services. Under this TRTA, ADB will also engage 4 near full-time individual 
consultants (3 international for 48 person-months, 1 national for 24 person-months) and short-
term consultants (an estimated 17 person-months of international/regional consultant inputs) 
using the individual consultant selection process. ADB will engage the consultants and firm 
following ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its associated 
project administration instructions and/or staff instructions. The TRTA resources will be disbursed 
following ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2020, as amended from time to 
time).  
 
III.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
19.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) providing the balance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a 
grant basis for the preparation for the ADB Ventures Investment Fund 2, and hereby reports this 
 
action to the Board.  
 
 
21 The Nordic Development Fund are considering cofinancing up to $500,000 towards the TRTA.

mobilize additional $500,000 cofinancing to increase the estimated cost to $1,000,000.
